description: From Middle English hyve, from Old English hȳf, from Proto-West Germanic *hūfi (compare Dutch huif (“beehive”), Danish dialect huv (“ship’s hull”)), from Proto-Indo-European *kuHp- (“water vessel”) (compare Latin cūpa (“tub, vat”), Ancient Greek κύπη (kúpē, “gap, hole”), κύπελλον (kúpellon, “beaker”), Sanskrit कूप (kū́pa, “cave”)), from *kew- (“to bend, curve”). The computing term was chosen as an in-joke relating to bees; see [1].

entries.meaning: A structure, whether artificial or natural, for housing a swarm of honeybees.
The bees of one hive; a swarm of bees.
A place swarming with busy occupants; a crowd.
(computing, Microsoft Windows) A section of the registry.
examples: For devices built with hive-based registry implementation, the registry data are broken into three different hives — the boot hive, system hive, and user hive.

verbs.description: hive (third-person singular simple present hives, present participle hiving, simple past and past participle hived)

examples: to hive a swarm of bees

entries.meaning: To store (something other than bees) in, or as if in, a hive.
To take lodging or shelter together; to reside in a collective body.
examples: […]  to get into warmer houses, and hive together in cities

entries.meaning: (entomology) Of insects: to enter or possess a hive.
